_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Famous Vineyards has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Famous Vineyards, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Famous Vineyards has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 Old Cold Storage          Anhydrous Ammonia                19,000

P2 New Cold Storage          Anhydrous Ammonia                120,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Pr

epared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Facility Layout



Sun Pacific Famous Vineyards operates a commercial cold storage for table grapes in Richgrove, CA. The facility has two (2) ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1 - Old Cold Storage

(7) Cold Storage Rooms

(3) Precool Rooms

(1) Hallway



Process 2 - New Cold Storage

(10) Cold Storage Rooms

(2) Precool Rooms

(2) Hallways

(1) Shipping Dock

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators, and the hydrocooler is equipped with air-cooling evaporators (bare coils) and an accumulator as required for flooded operation.

or 175 psig. All pressure relief valves for Process 1 terminate to atmosphere, while all pressure relief valves for Process 2 are piped to the ammonia diffusion tank.. One relief valve on each flooded accumulator dual assembly  is equipped with a rupture disc and non-resetting gauge to assist in recognizing that an overpressure event has occurred. The rupture discs are installed upstream of each relief valve and are designed to break at the relief valve set pressure. Once the rupture disc gauge has been broken, the gauge needle will move to the "burst" zone, indicating that the relief valve has lifted. The gauges can be manually reset.



Each main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. 



Process Classification



Each ammonia refrigeration system at Sun Pacific Famous Vineyards consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Sun Pacific Famous Vineyards are treated as two (2) independent processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Famous Vineyards has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders.

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration systems employed at Sun Pacific Famous Vineyards are flooded systems. In each system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers are piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator either feeds a hydrocooler, multiple bunker mounted or ceiling suspended evaporator coils located throughout the facility. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulators. For Process 2, any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receivers as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulators, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped t

o the suction inlet on the reciprocating, screw or upright compressors.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to the evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. Process 2 is also equipped with a thermosyphon vessel located between the evaporative condensers and high pressure receiver. The thermosyphon vessel supplies the screw compressor oil coolers with small amounts of high pressure liquid. As this liquid absorbs the heat from the oil, it evaporates inside the oil cooler, and returns to the thermosyphon vessel.

 

Safety Systems 



There are five (5) ammonia detection monitors installed at Sun Pacific Famous Vineyards. Each monitor is connected to multiple ammonia detectors installed in the rooms where ammonia provides refrigeration. The detection system is interlocked with the refrigeration system controls as follows:



If the ammonia concentration exceeds the set ppm, an audible alarm will be initiated throughout the facility, and a visual alarm will be initiated inside the electrical room above the ammonia detector monitors.



If the ammonia concentration exceeds the set ppm, the emergency ventilation systems in the machinery rooms will be activated.

The ammonia detection monitors provide ammonia detection as summarized below:



Process 1 - Old Cold Storage

Monitor #1

Rooms 1-8

Hallway

Monitor #2

Machinery Room

Precool 7



Process 2 - New Cold Storage

Monitor #1

Machinery Room

Monitor #2

Rooms 5-10

Shipping Dock

Monitor #3

East Hallway

Precooler 1-2

Rooms 1-4

West Hallway

 

The machinery room for Process 1 is equipped with a roof-mounted emergency ventilation fan, and the machinery room for Process 2 is equipped with two (2) roof-mounted emergency ventilation fans that automatically activate at the set ppm. Additionally, the emergency ventilation fan(s) serve to control the temperature within the machinery room and are automatically activated when the temperature inside the machinery room reaches a certain set-point. The emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the ON/AUTO switch located on the ventilation controls outside adjacent to the principal machinery room door.



The Emergency Control Box (ECB) for Process 2 was installed in accordance with the Fire Code at the time of construction. The ECB is installed on the south wall of the machinery room and contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. 



The Emergency Control Box is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment.



Each reciprocating and upright compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment.



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with pressure relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. The relief valves on the high side of each system relieve at 250 or 300 psig while the low side of each system relieves at 150

ility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History

Famous Vineyards has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Famous Vineyards' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strateg

ically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Famous Vineyards has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Famous Vineyards continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Famous Vineyards' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Famous Vineyards' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Famous Vineyards has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Famous Vineyards has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Famous Vineyards now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Famous Vineyards employees, but allows for feedback and continual
improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Famous Vineyards will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
